MINUTES (IN CHAMBERS) by Judge Andrew J. Guilford: Plaintiffs have filed a request for a ruling by the Court on all pending motions. (Dkt. No. 194.) The Court was prepared and about to issue rulings on those motions before receiving that request. But yesterday, the parties stipulated to file supplemental briefing regarding the status of one of the named plaintiffs. (Dkt. No. 196.) The Court granted that stipulation and is now waiting for Plaintiffs to file their reply to Defendants supplemental briefing. The Court will issue a ruling on all pending motions immediately after receiving Plaintiffs supplemental briefing. The Court GRANTS the request for a ruling. (Dkt. No. 194.) original_case_data.name: Glover v. City of Laguna Beach
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Homeless disabled individuals in Laguna Beach California
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
This lawsuit was brought by several homeless people with mental and physical disabilities against the City of Laguna Beach in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California. The plaintiffs, represented by the Southern California chapter of the ACLU and private counsel, accused the city and the Laguna Beach Police Department (LBPD) of violating the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12132), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (RA) (29 U.S.C. §§ 706, 794), and Article I, sections 7 and 17 of the California Constitution by targeting disabled homeless people under laws restricting camping in public spaces. The plaintiffs argued that the Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL), a small emergency shelter created by the county as part of the settlement of a previous lawsuit, did not provide adequate accommodations for homeless persons with disabilities, leaving them with no viable alternative to camping in public spaces. The plaintiffs brought their suit under 42 U.S.C. §1983, the Declaratory Judgement Act (28 U.S.C. §2201), and California law. They sought preliminary and permanent injunctive relief, declaratory relief, nominal damages, and attorneys’ fees. More specifically, the plaintiffs sought a declaration that the city was violating the law and an injunction preventing the city from enforcing anti-camping laws and requiring that the city provide new accommodations suitable for housing homeless people with disabilities.

On November 23, 2015, the plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction that would prevent the LBPD from enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people pending the final outcome of the suit. Judge Andrew J. Guilford denied the plaintiffs' motion on February 10, 2016, finding that the plaintiffs’ claims for injunctive relief were unlikely to succeed at trial.

On May 4, 2016, the plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint in order to introduce additional plaintiffs. Shortly thereafter, the plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification.

On October 31, 2016, both parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment. The plaintiffs moved for summary judgment to establish that the defendants violated (1) the prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments and analogous provisions of the California Constitution, and (2) Title II of the ADA and Section 504 of the RA. The defendants moved for summary judgment on all of the plaintiffs’ claims. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on the Eighth Amendment cruel and unusual punishment claims and the substantive due process claims. Judge Guilford denied both parties' motions for summary judgment on the ADA and RA claims.

On June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification in part, only with respect to the plaintiffs' remaining ADA and RA claims. The named plaintiffs represented a class consisting of "[a]ll homeless persons who reside or will reside in the geographic area of Laguna Beach who have a mental and/or physical disability as defined under section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and Americans with Disabilities Act and who have been, or are likely to be, cited for violations of California Penal Code section 647(e), Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 8.30.030 and/or Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 18.05.020."

Following nearly a year of settlement negotiations, during which the parties exchanged voluminous discovery and engaged multiple experts, the parties agreed to settle all claims in the lawsuit and filed a motion for preliminary approval of their proposed settlement agreement with the court on June 6, 2018. Under the terms of the Class Claims Settlement Agreement, the Laguna Beach City Council will adopt a resolution affirming its commitment to end homelessness in the City of Laguna Beach. Additionally, the City agreed to a number of measures designed to accommodate disabled persons experiencing homelessness in Laguna Beach. Such measures include, for instance, the continued designation of a full-time City employee to serve as the City’s “ADA Coordinator;” the adaptation of existing grievance procedures to more directly address the needs of ASL guests; the permanent posting of a Reasonable Accommodations Notice at the ASL explaining the process for requesting and obtaining reasonable accommodations; and more. The plaintiffs' counsel did not seek attorneys' fees.

On October 23, 2018, the parties filed a motion for final approval of their settlement agreement. Judge Guilford approved the motion on November 5, 2020. The court retains jurisdiction to enforce the settlement.
original_case_data.summary_short: Several disabled homeless persons sue the City of Luguna Beach, California, in the U.S. District Court of Central California, alleging that the Laguna Beach Police Department enforces anti-camping laws against them despite the city's failure to provide alternative housing that can accommodate their disabilities, in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S Constitution, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12132), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. §§ 706, 794), and Article I, sections 7 and 17 of the California Constitution. Judge Andrew J. Guilford granted the plaintiffs' motion for class-certification. After Judge Guilford ruled on cross-motions for summary judgment, the only remaining issues were the plaintiffs' ADA and RA claims. After extensive settlement negotiations, the parties agreed to a settlement, which the court continues to enforce.
original_case_data.summary_tiny: Disabled homeless people sue Laguna Beach California for anti-camping laws and lack of accommodations. @ACLU_SoCal

Represented by the Southern California chapter of the ACLU and private counsel, plaintiffs accused the city and the Laguna Beach Police Department (LBPD) of violating the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12132), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (RA) (29 U.S.C. §§ 706, 794), and Article I, sections 7 and 17 of the California Constitution by targeting disabled homeless people under laws restricting public camping. Plaintiffs argued the Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL), an emergency shelter created by the county from a previous settlement, did not adequately accommodate disabled homeless persons, leaving no viable alternative to public camping. The suit was brought under 42 U.S.C. §1983, the Declaratory Judgement Act (28 U.S.C. §2201), and California law. Plaintiffs sought preliminary and permanent injunctive relief, declaratory relief, nominal damages, and attorneys’ fees, specifically requesting a declaration of illegality and an injunction preventing anti-camping law enforcement while requiring new, suitable accommodations for disabled homeless individuals.

On November 23, 2015, plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction to prevent LBPD from enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people pending suit outcome. Judge Andrew J. Guilford denied the motion on February 10, 2016, finding injunctive relief claims unlikely to succeed.

Plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint to introduce additional plaintiffs, and subsequently moved for class certification.

Both parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment. Plaintiffs sought summary judgment to establish defendants violated (1) the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments' prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment and analogous California constitutional provisions, and (2) Title II of the ADA and Section 504 of the RA. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford granted defendants' motion on the Eighth Amendment cruel and unusual punishment and substantive due process claims, but denied both parties' motions on the ADA and RA claims.

On June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford granted plaintiffs' motion for class certification in part, limited to the remaining ADA and RA claims. The named plaintiffs represented a class of "[a]ll homeless persons who reside or will reside in the geographic area of Laguna Beach who have a mental and/or physical disability as defined under section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and Americans with Disabilities Act and who have been, or are likely to be, cited for violations of California Penal Code section 647(e), Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 8.30.030 and/or Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 18.05.020."

Following nearly a year of settlement negotiations, including voluminous discovery and expert engagement, the parties agreed to settle all claims and filed a motion for preliminary approval of their proposed settlement agreement. The City also agreed to measures accommodating disabled homeless persons, including designating a full-time ADA Coordinator, adapting grievance procedures for ASL guests, and permanently posting a Reasonable Accommodations Notice at the ASL explaining the request process. Plaintiffs' counsel did not seek attorneys' fees.

The parties filed a motion for final approval of their settlement agreement. Judge Guilford approved the motion on November 5, 2020. The court retains jurisdiction to enforce the settlement.

This lawsuit was initiated in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California by several homeless individuals with mental and physical disabilities against the City of Laguna Beach and its Police Department (LBPD). Represented by the Southern California chapter of the ACLU and private counsel, plaintiffs alleged violations of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12132), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (RA) (29 U.S.C. §§ 706, 794), and Article I, sections 7 and 17 of the California Constitution. Plaintiffs contended that defendants targeted disabled homeless persons through anti-camping laws, asserting that the county-created Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL) emergency shelter failed to adequately accommodate disabled homeless individuals, thereby providing no viable alternative to public camping. The suit was brought under 42 U.S.C. §1983, the Declaratory Judgment Act (28 U.S.C. §2201), and California law. Plaintiffs sought preliminary and permanent injunctive relief, declaratory relief, nominal damages, and attorneys’ fees, specifically requesting a declaration of illegality and an injunction preventing anti-camping law enforcement while requiring new, suitable accommodations for disabled homeless individuals.

On November 23, 2015, plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction to prevent LBPD from enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people pending the suit's outcome. Judge Andrew J. Guilford denied the motion on February 10, 2016, concluding that injunctive relief claims were unlikely to succeed. Plaintiffs subsequently filed a second amended complaint to introduce additional plaintiffs and moved for class certification.

Both parties later filed cross-motions for summary judgment. Plaintiffs sought summary judgment to establish defendants violated (1) the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments' prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment and analogous California constitutional provisions, and (2) Title II of the ADA and Section 504 of the RA. Defendants moved for summary judgment on all claims. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford granted defendants' motion on the Eighth Amendment cruel and unusual punishment and substantive due process claims, but denied both parties' motions on the ADA and RA claims. Shortly thereafter, on June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford granted plaintiffs' motion for class certification in part, limiting it to the remaining ADA and RA claims. The named plaintiffs represented a class of "[a]ll homeless persons who reside or will reside in the geographic area of Laguna Beach who have a mental and/or physical disability as defined under section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and Americans with Disabilities Act and who have been, or are likely to be, cited for violations of California Penal Code section 647(e), Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 8.30.030 and/or Laguna Beach Municipal Code section 18.05.020."

Following nearly a year of comprehensive settlement negotiations, the parties agreed to resolve all claims and filed a motion for preliminary approval of their proposed Class Claims Settlement Agreement. Under the terms, the Laguna Beach City Council committed to adopting a resolution affirming its dedication to ending homelessness in the City. The City also agreed to implement specific measures accommodating disabled homeless persons, including designating a full-time ADA Coordinator, adapting grievance procedures for ASL guests, and permanently posting a Reasonable Accommodations Notice at the ASL explaining the request process. Plaintiffs' counsel did not seek attorneys' fees. The parties subsequently filed a motion for final approval of the settlement agreement, which Judge Guilford approved on November 5, 2020. The court retains jurisdiction to enforce the settlement.

This lawsuit was filed by several homeless people with mental and physical disabilities against the City of Laguna Beach in a federal court in California. The plaintiffs, represented by the Southern California ACLU and private lawyers, claimed the city and its police department (LBPD) broke several laws. They argued the city violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Rehabilitation Act (RA), and parts of the California Constitution. Their main point was that the city targeted disabled homeless people through laws that banned camping in public areas. The plaintiffs argued that the Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL), a small emergency shelter set up by the county after an earlier lawsuit, did not properly accommodate homeless people with disabilities. This left them with no real choice but to camp in public spaces. The plaintiffs filed their case using specific federal laws (like 42 U.S.C. §1983 and the Declaratory Judgment Act) and California state law. They asked the court for several things: temporary and permanent orders to stop the city's actions (injunctive relief), a formal statement from the court about the law (declaratory relief), small damages, and their legal fees. More specifically, they wanted the court to declare that the city was breaking the law. They also sought an order to prevent the city from enforcing anti-camping laws and to make the city provide suitable new housing options for disabled homeless people.

On November 23, 2015, the plaintiffs asked for a temporary court order (a preliminary injunction) to stop the LBPD from enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people while the lawsuit was ongoing. Judge Andrew J. Guilford denied this request on February 10, 2016. He found that the plaintiffs' arguments for this temporary order were unlikely to win at a full trial.

On May 4, 2016, the plaintiffs filed an updated complaint to add more plaintiffs to the case. Soon after, the plaintiffs asked the court to certify the case as a class action.

On October 31, 2016, both sides filed motions asking the judge to rule in their favor without a full trial (summary judgment). The plaintiffs' motion aimed to prove that the defendants violated laws against cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments (and similar parts of the California Constitution), as well as the ADA and RA. The defendants, on the other hand, asked for summary judgment on all of the plaintiffs' claims, seeking to dismiss them. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford sided with the defendants on some points, granting their request to dismiss the cruel and unusual punishment claims (under the Eighth Amendment) and the substantive due process claims. However, he denied both sides' requests for summary judgment regarding the ADA and RA claims, meaning those claims would proceed.

On June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford partially approved the plaintiffs' request for class certification, but only for the remaining ADA and RA claims. The named plaintiffs would represent a group (a class) of "all homeless persons in Laguna Beach who have a mental or physical disability, as defined by the Rehabilitation Act and Americans with Disabilities Act, and who have been, or might be, cited for violating specific anti-camping laws (California Penal Code section 647(e) and Laguna Beach Municipal Code sections 8.30.030 and 18.05.020)."

After nearly a year of settlement talks, where both sides shared a lot of information and brought in many experts, the parties agreed to settle all parts of the lawsuit. They filed a motion with the court on June 6, 2018, asking for initial approval of their proposed settlement agreement. Under the terms of the Class Claims Settlement Agreement, the Laguna Beach City Council committed to adopting a resolution to end homelessness in the city. Additionally, the City agreed to several steps designed to help disabled homeless people in Laguna Beach. These steps include, for example, keeping a full-time City employee as the "ADA Coordinator," changing existing complaint procedures to better serve ASL guests, and permanently posting a notice at the ASL explaining how to ask for and get reasonable accommodations. The plaintiffs' lawyers did not ask for their legal fees.

On October 23, 2018, the parties filed a motion for the court's final approval of their settlement agreement. Judge Guilford approved this motion on November 5, 2020. The court will continue to oversee the settlement to ensure it is followed.

A group of homeless people with mental and physical disabilities sued the City of Laguna Beach in a federal court in California. They argued the city violated parts of the U.S. Constitution: the Eighth Amendment (which protects against cruel and unusual punishment, like how the police treat people) and the Fourteenth Amendment (which says everyone deserves fair treatment and equal protection under the law). They also said the city broke laws like the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (RA), which are designed to protect people with disabilities, and even parts of California's own Constitution. Their main point was that the city's laws, which banned camping in public places, unfairly targeted homeless people who had disabilities. The plaintiffs argued that a special shelter called the Alternative Sleeping Location (ASL), which was set up after an earlier lawsuit, wasn't good enough for homeless people with disabilities. This meant they had no real option but to camp outside in public. They brought their case using federal laws that let people sue the government when their civil rights are violated, and also to ask a court to clearly state what the law means. They also used California state law. They asked the court to order the city to stop its actions, both temporarily and permanently. They also wanted the court to officially say the city was breaking the law, give them a small amount of money for damages, and make the city pay for their lawyers' fees. They specifically wanted the court to stop the city from enforcing its anti-camping laws and to make the city provide suitable new housing options for disabled homeless people.

On November 23, 2015, the plaintiffs asked the court for a temporary order, like a "pause button," to stop the police from enforcing anti-camping laws against disabled homeless people while the lawsuit was still going on. Judge Andrew J. Guilford said "no" to this request on February 10, 2016. He felt that the plaintiffs' arguments for this temporary "pause button" probably wouldn't win if the case went to a full trial.

On May 4, 2016, the plaintiffs changed their lawsuit papers to include more people who were also suing the city. Soon after, the plaintiffs asked the court to let their case be a "class action." This means one lawsuit could represent a whole group of people who had similar problems with the city, like a team representing many players.

On October 31, 2016, both sides asked the judge to make a decision in their favor without having a full trial. This is called "summary judgment," like asking the teacher for a final grade based on your work so far, without needing a big final exam. The plaintiffs tried to show that the city broke laws against cruel and unusual punishment (from the U.S. Constitution's Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments and similar California laws), and also the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (RA). The city, on the other hand, asked the judge to dismiss *all* of the plaintiffs' claims, saying they had no case. On June 25, 2017, Judge Guilford agreed with the city on some points. He dismissed the claims about cruel and unusual punishment (Eighth Amendment) and the claims about their basic rights to fair treatment. But he said 'no' to both sides' requests about the ADA and RA claims, meaning those parts of the lawsuit would continue.

On June 23, 2017, Judge Guilford partly agreed to the plaintiffs' request for a "class action," but only for the remaining claims about the ADA and RA. The main plaintiffs would now represent a larger group, or "class," of "all homeless people in Laguna Beach with a mental or physical disability, as defined by the Rehabilitation Act and Americans with Disabilities Act, who have been, or could be, ticketed for breaking specific anti-camping laws."

After almost a year of talks, where both sides shared lots of information and brought in many experts, everyone involved agreed to settle the entire lawsuit. They filed a request with the court on June 6, 2018, asking for initial approval of the agreement they had worked out. Under the agreement, called the Class Claims Settlement Agreement, the Laguna Beach City Council promised to officially commit to ending homelessness in the city. Also, the City agreed to several actions to help disabled homeless people in Laguna Beach. These steps included, for example, keeping a full-time city employee as the "ADA Coordinator" (someone who helps make sure the city follows disability laws), changing how people can complain to better help those staying at the ASL shelter, and putting up a permanent notice at the ASL explaining how to ask for and get special help or changes (called "reasonable accommodations"). The lawyers for the homeless people did not ask for their legal fees.

On October 23, 2018, both sides asked the court for final approval of their settlement agreement. Judge Guilford gave his final approval on November 5, 2020. The court will keep an eye on the settlement to make sure everyone follows the agreement.

Recognizing the need to broaden their collective voice, the plaintiffs later amended their complaint to include additional individuals and then sought to certify their case as a class action. This strategic decision aimed to allow the lawsuit to proceed on behalf of a larger group of similarly situated disabled homeless individuals, significantly expanding the potential impact of any favorable outcome.

As the litigation progressed, both sides sought summary judgment, a maneuver to resolve parts or all of the case without a full trial. The plaintiffs hoped to secure a ruling that the city had undeniably violated constitutional and disability rights, while the defendants aimed for a complete dismissal of all claims against them. The court, however, delivered a mixed outcome: it sided with the city on the constitutional claims related to cruel and unusual punishment and due process, but determined that the core disability rights claims under the ADA and RA still presented genuine issues requiring further examination.

Crucially, the court did grant the plaintiffs' request for class certification, though specifically for their remaining ADA and RA claims. This meant that the lawsuit could now proceed representing a defined group of disabled homeless individuals in Laguna Beach who had been, or were likely to be, cited under the contested anti-camping laws.

After nearly a year of intense negotiations, the parties decided to pursue a settlement, recognizing the complexities and costs of a prolonged legal battle. This agreement offered a path to a resolution that addressed the plaintiffs' concerns without the uncertainty of a trial. Under the terms, the City of Laguna Beach committed to a resolution affirming its dedication to ending homelessness and, more specifically, agreed to implement various measures to better accommodate disabled homeless individuals. These included appointing an ADA Coordinator, improving grievance procedures at the ASL, and publicly posting information about reasonable accommodations. Notably, the plaintiffs' counsel chose not to seek attorneys' fees, underscoring their focus on the substantive changes for the community.

The settlement received final judicial approval, bringing a definitive end to the dispute. The court retained jurisdiction, ensuring its ability to oversee the city's compliance with the agreed-upon terms.

original_case_data.name: Sostre v. Preiser
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Martin Sostre, a prison activist incarcerated in New York state prisons.
original_case_data.summary:
This is a historic case about prisoner rights in New York prisons. It's part of the Clearinghouse's collection of several cases brought by prisoners rights activist (and prisoner) Martin Sostre, whose wikipedia biography is here. 

On September 18, 1973, Sostre filed this lawsuit, pro se, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York. He sued New York State’s Commissioner of Corrections and the Wardens of Auburn and Clinton Prisons under §1983 a few days after he was allegedly beaten in the Segregation Unit at Clinton Prison, by a squad of seven or more officers, when he refused to bend over and spread his buttocks to exhibit his anus to them in the course of a strip search. The Complaint asserted seventeen separate causes of action, including wrongful punishment and indefinite confinement to segregation, wrongful application of the no-beard rule, wrongful imposition of the rectal search, wrongful denial of visits from attorneys, clergy and friends, interference with mail, and wrongful punitive transfer from Auburn to Clinton. Sostre sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and money damages.

On September 14, 1973, Judge Edmund Port entered an order finding the complaint sufficient in law to permit the plaintiff to proceed in forma pauperis. The case then lay dormant in the Northern District for sixteen months until Sostre was able to obtain counsel; starting February, 1975, he was represented by radical prisoners’ rights lawyers Michael Deutsch and Dennis Cunningham. 

Once Sostre obtained counsel, the Court agreed to hear his motion for preliminary relief, and entered an order directing that the plaintiff be brought into federal custody so he would not again have to face the forcible search and re-confinement to the Segregation Unit. On March 4 and 5, 1975, a hearing was held pertaining to Sostre’s request for preliminary relief. That request included that the defendants be enjoined from (1) enforcing a rule or regulation prohibiting inmates at Clinton Correctional Facility from wearing a beard; (2) continuing to punish plaintiff for violating the no-beard rule or regulation; and (3) requiring the plaintiff to submit to a rectal search upon entering and leaving a Special Housing Unit at Clinton Correctional Facility.

The district court denied preliminary relief, finding that plaintiff failed to show likely success on the merits and irreparable injury. Judge Port ordered Sostre returned to the custody of the Clinton Prison. However, this order was stayed, with the agreement of defendants, pending disposition of plaintiff's appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

On June 19, 1975, the appeals court reversed the district court's denial of preliminary relief and remanded the matter to the district court. In an opinion written by Judge Oakes, the Second Circuit concluded that it could not rule on the relief sought because the record did not establish what the "no-beard" and "rectal search" rules, if they were such, required. Without knowing what the rules said, the court determined it could not ascertain whether the rules had been properly applied. It remanded the case to the district court for record development and re-evaluation. The opinion, however, reaffirmed that prison inmates are entitled to certain fundamental rights, and stated that limitations on such rights "must be supported by the legitimate and reasonable needs and exigencies of the institutional environment," and that these limitations must be narrowly tailored. The opinion also stated that the district court would not be amiss were it to continue the stay order in effect to keep plaintiff in federal custody. 519 F.2d 763

By this time, Sostre had gained international news media attention and been labeled as a "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International. In December 1975, New York's governor Hugh Carey granted Sostre clemency, and he was released from custody. Presumably, this case was mooted as a result; federal records show that the case officially ended on Jan. 18, 1978.
original_case_data.summary_short: Sostre, an incarcerated individual, sued  the Commissioner of Corrections and the Wardens of Auburn and Clinton Prisons under §1983. Plaintiff alleged seventeen separate causes of action including wrongful punishment and indefinite confinement to segregation, wrongful application of the no-beard rule, wrongful imposition of the rectal search, and more. Plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and money damages. Preliminary relief was denied by the district court, and on appeal, the appellate court reversed this decision and remanded the matter for development of a more detailed record. A few months later, Sostre was granted clemency by the New York Governor.
original_case_data.summary_tiny: New to the Sostre Collection at the Clearinghouse: a case by Sostre challenging the no-beard and rectal search rules at a prison in NY.

This historic case, part of a collection involving prisoner rights activist Martin Sostre, addresses fundamental prisoner rights in New York.

On September 18, 1973, Sostre, proceeding pro se, initiated this §1983 action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York. He sued the New York State Commissioner of Corrections and the Wardens of Auburn and Clinton Prisons. The lawsuit followed an alleged beating in Clinton Prison's Segregation Unit after Sostre refused a rectal strip search. His seventeen-count Complaint asserted claims including wrongful punishment and indefinite segregation, wrongful application of the no-beard rule, improper rectal search, denial of attorney, clergy, and friend visits, mail interference, and wrongful punitive transfer from Auburn to Clinton. Sostre sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and money damages.

On September 14, 1973, Judge Edmund Port entered an order finding the complaint sufficient in law to permit Sostre to proceed in forma pauperis. The case remained dormant for sixteen months until Sostre secured counsel, Michael Deutsch and Dennis Cunningham, in February 1975.

Upon obtaining counsel, Sostre moved for preliminary relief. The Court ordered his transfer to federal custody to prevent further forcible searches and re-confinement to the Segregation Unit. A hearing was held regarding Sostre’s request, which sought to enjoin defendants from enforcing the no-beard rule, punishing him for its violation, and requiring rectal searches upon entering or leaving a Special Housing Unit at Clinton Correctional Facility.

The district court denied preliminary relief, finding Sostre failed to show likely success on the merits and irreparable injury. Judge Port ordered Sostre returned to the custody of Clinton Prison. However, this order was stayed, with the defendants' agreement, pending disposition of Sostre's appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

On June 19, 1975, the Second Circuit, in an opinion by Judge Oakes, reversed the district court's denial of preliminary relief and remanded the matter. It remanded the case to the district court for record development and re-evaluation. The opinion reaffirmed that prison inmates possess fundamental rights, stating that any limitations must be supported by legitimate and reasonable institutional exigencies and be narrowly tailored. It also noted the district court could maintain the stay order to keep Sostre in federal custody. (519 F.2d 763).

Sostre garnered international attention, recognized as a "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International. In December 1975, New York's governor Hugh Carey granted Sostre clemency, and he was released from custody. This rendered the case moot, with federal records indicating its official termination on January 18, 1978.

1.transformed_text:
This is a significant case concerning prisoner rights in New York prisons. It is part of the Clearinghouse's collection of several cases brought by the well-known prisoners' rights advocate (and prisoner) Martin Sostre, whose Wikipedia biography is available online.

On September 18, 1973, Sostre filed this lawsuit on his own behalf in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York. He sued New York State's Commissioner of Corrections and the Wardens of Auburn and Clinton Prisons, claiming they violated his civil rights under a specific federal law (Section 1983). This happened a few days after he was allegedly beaten in the isolation unit at Clinton Prison by a group of seven or more officers. This occurred when he refused to submit to a strip search that required him to expose his anus. His lawsuit listed seventeen separate claims, including unfair punishment and indefinite confinement to isolation, unfair enforcement of the no-beard rule, unfair requirement of a rectal search, unfair denial of visits from his lawyers, religious leaders, and friends, interference with his mail, and an unfair transfer as punishment from Auburn to Clinton. Sostre asked the court to declare his rights, order the prison to stop certain actions, and pay him money for damages.

On September 14, 1973, Judge Edmund Port issued an order allowing Sostre to proceed with his lawsuit without paying court fees, as he was unable to afford them. The case then remained inactive in the Northern District for sixteen months until Sostre found legal representation. Starting in February 1975, he was represented by Michael Deutsch and Dennis Cunningham, who were lawyers specializing in prisoners' rights.

Once Sostre had lawyers, the Court agreed to hear his request for a temporary order. It issued an order to transfer Sostre to federal custody. This was to prevent him from facing the forced search and being sent back to the isolation unit. On March 4 and 5, 1975, a hearing was held regarding Sostre's request for temporary relief. His request asked the court to order the defendants to stop: (1) enforcing a rule that stopped inmates at Clinton Correctional Facility from wearing a beard; (2) continuing to punish Sostre for breaking the no-beard rule; and (3) requiring Sostre to undergo a rectal search when entering and leaving a Special Housing Unit at Clinton Correctional Facility.

The district court denied this temporary relief. It found that Sostre had not shown he was likely to win the case or that he would suffer harm that could not be fixed later. Judge Port ordered Sostre to be sent back to Clinton Prison. However, this order was put on hold, with the defendants' agreement, until Sostre's appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit was decided.

On June 19, 1975, the appeals court overturned the district court's decision to deny temporary relief and sent the case back to the district court. In an opinion by Judge Oakes, the Second Circuit decided it could not rule on the requested relief. This was because the court records did not clearly show what the "no-beard" and "rectal search" rules, if they existed, actually required. Without knowing the exact rules, the court could not tell if they had been applied correctly. It sent the case back to the district court to gather more facts and reconsider the matter. However, the opinion confirmed that prisoners have certain basic rights. It stated that any limits on these rights "must be based on the valid and practical needs of the prison setting," and that these limits must be carefully designed to be as minimal as possible. The opinion also suggested that the district court would be right to keep the stay order in place, allowing Sostre to remain in federal custody. 519 F.2d 763

By this time, Sostre had gained international news media attention and been labeled a "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International. In December 1975, New York's Governor Hugh Carey granted Sostre clemency, which led to his release from prison. This likely made the case irrelevant, as Sostre was no longer in prison. Federal records indicate the case officially closed on January 18, 1978.

In a written decision by Judge Oakes, the Second Circuit said it could not rule on the requested relief. This was because court records did not clearly show what the "no-beard" and "rectal search" rules, if they existed, actually required. Without knowing the exact rules, the court could not tell if they had been applied fairly. It sent the case back to the lower court to gather more facts and reconsider the issue. However, the appeals court's decision confirmed that prisoners have certain basic rights. It stated that any limits on these rights "must be based on the valid and practical needs of the prison setting," and that these limits must be carefully designed to be as minimal as possible. The decision also suggested that the lower court would be right to keep the stay order in place, allowing Sostre to remain in federal custody.

By this time, Sostre had gained international news media attention and was labeled a "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International. In December 1975, New York's Governor Hugh Carey granted Sostre clemency, which is a form of pardon that led to his release from prison. This likely made the case irrelevant, as Sostre was no longer in prison. Federal records show the case officially closed on January 18, 1978.

This is an important case about the rights of people in prison in New York. It's one of several cases brought by the well-known activist Martin Sostre, who fought for the rights of prisoners.

On September 18, 1973, Sostre, acting as his own lawyer, started this lawsuit in a federal court in Northern New York. He sued the person in charge of all New York State prisons and the wardens (heads) of Auburn and Clinton Prisons. He said they violated his civil rights, which are basic freedoms protected by the Constitution. He sued them using a federal law called Section 1983, which lets people take government officials to court if those officials break their constitutional rights. Think of it like a special rule that allows you to hold government workers accountable if they overstep. This happened a few days after he was supposedly beaten by several officers in a special isolation unit (like solitary confinement) in prison. This occurred when he refused a strip search where he had to show his anus. His lawsuit listed 17 different complaints. These included unfair punishment, being held in isolation for too long, unfairly being forced to follow a rule against having a beard, being forced to have a rectal search, not being allowed to see his lawyers, religious leaders, or friends, his mail being messed with, and being unfairly moved as punishment from Auburn Prison to Clinton Prison. Sostre asked the court to clearly state what his rights were, order the prison to stop doing certain things, and pay him money for the harm he suffered.

On September 14, 1973, Judge Edmund Port allowed Sostre to move forward with his lawsuit without having to pay court fees, because he couldn't afford them. This is like getting a waiver for a school fee if you can't pay. The case then paused for 16 months until Sostre found lawyers. Starting in February 1975, two lawyers named Michael Deutsch and Dennis Cunningham, who focused on prisoner rights, began representing him.

Once Sostre had lawyers, the court agreed to hear his request for a temporary order, which is like asking for a quick fix while the main case is still going on. The court ordered Sostre to be moved into federal custody (meaning he was held by the federal government, not the state prison). This was to keep him from facing the forced search again and being sent back to the isolation unit. On March 4 and 5, 1975, a hearing (a formal meeting in court) was held about Sostre's request for this temporary help. He asked the prison officials to stop: (1) making prisoners at Clinton Correctional Facility follow a rule that banned beards; (2) punishing Sostre for breaking that no-beard rule; and (3) making him have a rectal search every time he entered or left a Special Housing Unit (a specific part of the prison).

The lower court (the first court to hear the case) said no to this temporary request. It said Sostre hadn't shown he was likely to win his main case, nor that he would suffer harm that couldn't be fixed later on. Judge Port ordered Sostre to be sent back to Clinton Prison. But this order was put on hold (paused), with the prison officials agreeing, until Sostre's appeal to a higher court, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, was decided. Think of an appeal like asking a higher authority to review a decision you disagree with.

On June 19, 1975, the appeals court (the higher court) reversed the lower court's decision to deny temporary help. It sent the case back to the lower court to look at it again. In a written decision by Judge Oakes, the Second Circuit (the appeals court) said it couldn't make a decision on the help Sostre asked for. This was because the court's records didn't clearly show what the "no-beard" and "rectal search" rules, if they even existed, actually said or required. Without knowing the exact rules, the court couldn't tell if they had been used fairly. So, it sent the case back to the lower court to gather more information and think about the issue again. However, the appeals court's decision did confirm that people in prison still have certain basic rights. It said that any limits on these rights "must be based on the real and practical needs of running a prison," and that these limits must be designed very carefully to be as small as possible. This is like a school rule: it has to have a good reason and shouldn't be more restrictive than it needs to be. The decision also suggested that the lower court would be right to keep the pause order in place, allowing Sostre to remain in federal custody.

By this time, Sostre had become known around the world, getting attention from news outlets and being called a "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International, a group that advocates for human rights. In December 1975, New York's Governor Hugh Carey gave Sostre "clemency," which is like a special forgiveness that led to his release from prison. It's similar to a president pardoning someone. This probably made the case unimportant, since Sostre was no longer in prison and the issues were about his time there. Official government records show the case was formally closed on January 18, 1978.

0.text:
This is a historic case about prisoner rights in New York prisons. It's part of the Clearinghouse's collection of several cases brought by prisoners rights activist (and prisoner) Martin Sostre, whose wikipedia biography is here. 

On September 18, 1973, Sostre filed this lawsuit, pro se, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York. He sued New York State’s Commissioner of Corrections and the Wardens of Auburn and Clinton Prisons under §1983 a few days after he was allegedly beaten in the Segregation Unit at Clinton Prison, by a squad of seven or more officers, when he refused to bend over and spread his buttocks to exhibit his anus to them in the course of a strip search. The Complaint asserted seventeen separate causes of action, including wrongful punishment and indefinite confinement to segregation, wrongful application of the no-beard rule, wrongful imposition of the rectal search, wrongful denial of visits from attorneys, clergy and friends, interference with mail, and wrongful punitive transfer from Auburn to Clinton. Sostre sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and money damages.

On September 14, 1973, Judge Edmund Port entered an order finding the complaint sufficient in law to permit the plaintiff to proceed in forma pauperis. The case then lay dormant in the Northern District for sixteen months until Sostre was able to obtain counsel; starting February, 1975, he was represented by radical prisoners’ rights lawyers Michael Deutsch and Dennis Cunningham. 

Once Sostre obtained counsel, the Court agreed to hear his motion for preliminary relief, and entered an order directing that the plaintiff be brought into federal custody so he would not again have to face the forcible search and re-confinement to the Segregation Unit. On March 4 and 5, 1975, a hearing was held pertaining to Sostre’s request for preliminary relief. That request included that the defendants be enjoined from (1) enforcing a rule or regulation prohibiting inmates at Clinton Correctional Facility from wearing a beard; (2) continuing to punish plaintiff for violating the no-beard rule or regulation; and (3) requiring the plaintiff to submit to a rectal search upon entering and leaving a Special Housing Unit at Clinton Correctional Facility.

The district court denied preliminary relief, finding that plaintiff failed to show likely success on the merits and irreparable injury. Judge Port ordered Sostre returned to the custody of the Clinton Prison. However, this order was stayed, with the agreement of defendants, pending disposition of plaintiff's appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

On June 19, 1975, the appeals court reversed the district court's denial of preliminary relief and remanded the matter to the district court. In an opinion written by Judge Oakes, the Second Circuit concluded that it could not rule on the relief sought because the record did not establish what the "no-beard" and "rectal search" rules, if they were such, required. Without knowing what the rules said, the court determined it could not ascertain whether the rules had been properly applied. It remanded the case to the district court for record development and re-evaluation. The opinion, however, reaffirmed that prison inmates are entitled to certain fundamental rights, and stated that limitations on such rights "must be supported by the legitimate and reasonable needs and exigencies of the institutional environment," and that these limitations must be narrowly tailored. The opinion also stated that the district court would not be amiss were it to continue the stay order in effect to keep plaintiff in federal custody. 519 F.2d 763

By this time, Sostre had gained international news media attention and been labeled as a "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International. In December 1975, New York's governor Hugh Carey granted Sostre clemency, and he was released from custody. Presumably, this case was mooted as a result; federal records show that the case officially ended on Jan. 18, 1978.

1.transformed_text:
This is a historic case about prisoner rights in New York, part of a collection of legal challenges brought by the activist and prisoner, Martin Sostre.

On September 18, 1973, Sostre launched a legal challenge on his own behalf, suing New York State’s Commissioner of Corrections and the Wardens of Auburn and Clinton Prisons. He did so just days after allegedly enduring a brutal beating in Clinton Prison's Segregation Unit, inflicted by a squad of officers when he refused a humiliating strip search. His claims encompassed seventeen distinct grievances, including wrongful punishment, indefinite solitary confinement, the arbitrary enforcement of a no-beard rule, the imposition of invasive rectal searches, denial of visits, interference with mail, and a punitive transfer. Through this lawsuit, Sostre sought not only to declare these practices unlawful and halt them, but also to secure compensation for his suffering.

The court acknowledged the gravity of his allegations, allowing him to proceed despite his lack of funds. The legal battle then paused for sixteen months, awaiting the arrival of dedicated legal representation, which he found in February 1975, when radical prisoners' rights lawyers Michael Deutsch and Dennis Cunningham joined his cause.

Once Sostre secured counsel, the court agreed to hear his urgent plea for immediate protection. Recognizing the immediate threat to his safety, it ordered his transfer into federal custody, shielding him from further punitive searches and solitary confinement. A hearing was convened in March 1975 to consider Sostre's plea for immediate intervention. His request sought to halt the prison's enforcement of its no-beard policy, end his punishment for defying it, and prevent the continued imposition of invasive rectal searches.

However, the district court ultimately refused this immediate protection, concluding that Sostre had not yet demonstrated a high probability of winning his case or suffering irreversible harm. This decision meant Sostre was to be returned to Clinton Prison, exposing him once more to the very conditions he challenged. Yet, in a crucial turn, the defendants agreed to a stay, allowing Sostre to remain in federal custody while he pursued an appeal to the Second Circuit, buying him time and preventing his immediate return to the harsh prison environment.

The appeals court, however, intervened, overturning the lower court's refusal of immediate relief and sending the case back for further consideration. The Second Circuit, in an opinion by Judge Oakes, found itself unable to fully address Sostre's claims because the specifics of the prison's "no-beard" and "rectal search" policies were unclear in the existing record. To ensure a just decision, it directed the lower court to gather more information, allowing for a proper assessment of whether these rules were legitimate and applied fairly. Crucially, the appellate court used this opportunity to firmly reassert that prisoners retain fundamental rights, emphasizing that any restrictions on these rights must be genuinely necessary for institutional security and narrowly tailored to achieve that purpose. It also advised the district court to maintain Sostre in federal custody, acknowledging the ongoing need for his protection.

While his legal battle continued, Sostre's plight had resonated far beyond the courtroom, earning him international media attention and the designation of "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International. Ultimately, his release came not from a court order, but from a grant of clemency by New York Governor Hugh Carey in December 1975, effectively rendering his legal fight for freedom unnecessary. Though the case formally concluded years later, his release marked the practical end of this significant chapter in prisoner rights history.

ORDER ON MOTION FOR PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION (DKT. NO.  65 ). Plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction   is GRANTED. Defendants are HEREBY ENJOINED from enforcing SB 5375 as to the Sacrament of Confession against the Plaintiffs in this acti on and all Roman Catholic priests in Washington who fall directly under the administration of Plaintiffs Etienne, Daly, and Tyson. The Court does not reach Plaintiff's Church Autonomy Doctrine and Establishment Clause claims at this juncture.  Signed  by U.S. District Judge David G Estudillo. (MW)

Order re Plaintiffs' 65 Stipulated Motion to Stay Proceedings and Enter Preliminary Injunction as to County Prosecutor Defendants.Defendants Leesa Manion, Larry Haskell, Joseph Brusic, Randy Flyckt, Curt Liedkie, Eric Eisinger, Robert Sealby, Mark Nichols, Tony Golik, Dale Slack, Ryan Jurvakainen, James Mitchell, Michael Golden, Shawn Sant, Mathew Newberg, Kevin McRae, Norma Tillotson, Gregory Banks, James Kennedy, Chad Enright, Gregory Zempel, David Quesnel, Jonathan Meyer, Ty Albertson, Michael Dorcy, Albert Lin, Michael Rothman, Dolly Hunt, Mary Robnett, Amy Vira, Rich Weyrich, Adam Kick, Jason Cummings, Erika George, Jon Tunheim, Dan Bigelow, Gabe Acosta, Eric Richey, and Denis Tracy (the Stipulating Defendants) have agreed, in exchange for Plaintiffs' agreement to stay the lawsuit against them, to stipulate to the Courts entry of the Plaintiffs' proposed preliminary injunction pending the Courts final judgment in this case, including during the pendency of any potential interlocutory appeal. The Stipulating Defendants are hereby subject to and bound by Exhibit A to this Order. Plaintiffs' action against the Stipulating Defendants shall be STAYED until the entry of a final judgment in this matter as to all other defendants. During the pendency of the stay, the Stipulating Defendants' deadline to respond to the Complaint and all other case deadlines applicable to the Stipulating Defendants shall be STRICKEN. The Stipulating Defendants will not appeal any interlocutory ruling in this matter, including but not limited to the Court's ruling on Plaintiffs' Motion for Preliminary Injunction (Dkt. 65 ). The Stipulating Defendants will consent to the Court's final judgment against the remaining defendants and will not appeal any such judgment. In consideration of these mutual agreements, Plaintiffs will not seek attorneys' fees and/or costs from the Stipulating Defendants at the conclusion of this matter and regardless of the Court's final judgment. The Stipulating Defendants likewise waive any claim for attorneys' fees and/or costs from the Plaintiffs, regardless of the Court's final judgment. Signed by U.S. District Judge David G Estudillo.(MDH) (Entered: 07/15/2025)

original_case_data.name: Etienne v. Ferguson
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Eleven Catholic archbishops and priests in the U.S. state of Washington.
special_collections: Trump Administration 2.0: Litigation and Investigations Involving the Government
Trump Administration 2.0: Litigation and Investigations Involving the Government
original_case_data.summary:
This case challenged a Washington state law, SB 5375, which required priests to report any suspected child abuse or neglect disclosed by penitents in confession. Confession is one of the seven sacraments of the Catholic Church and has been an integral part of its theology for two millennia. "Eternal damnation" and automatic excommunication from the Catholic Church await any priest who breaks the confidentiality of confession.

Washington's three Catholic dioceses already mandated reporting for suspected child abuse and neglect, beyond the requirements of state law, with the sole exception of information learned exclusively via confession. Plaintiffs alleged the new state law violated the First Amendment, the Equal Protection Clause, and the Washington Constitution.

Represented by Wilmer Hale and the Becket Fund for religious liberty, plaintiffs, eleven Catholic archbishops and priests, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington on May 29, 2025. The lawsuit named the Governor and Attorney General of the state of Washington and every County Prosecuting Attorney in the state as defendants. Plaintiffs sought a declaration that the state law was unconstitutional, a preliminary and permanent injunction against the criminal investigation of Catholic priests under the law, and attorneys' fees. The case was assigned to Judge David G. Estudillo.

The United States moved to intervene in this case as plaintiff on June 23, 2025. The court granted the motion to intervene on July 15, 2025, reserving for a later date its ruling on the scope of relief the United States was entitled to seek. The United States filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, separate from plaintiffs' earlier motion for the same, on June 25, 2025.

On July 18, 2025, the court granted plaintiffs' (not the United States') motion for a preliminary injunction. The court found that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claims that SB 5375 violated the Free Exercise Clause, as it burdened plaintiffs' exercise of their Catholic faith and because it modified existing law solely for clergy as opposed to secular mandated reporters. Further, the court found that the law failed strict scrutiny, as Washington could have followed the less restrictive example of 25 other states in making Catholic clergymen mandated reporters while excluding information learned solely from confession from reporting duties.

The court declined to reach plaintiffs' Church Autonomy Doctrine and Establishment Clause claims. Defendants were thus enjoined from enforcing SB 5375 as to the sacrament of confession across all three of Washington's Catholic dioceses. (Plaintiffs did not seek, and the court did not grant, injunctive relief to faiths other than Catholicism.)

On July 23, 2025, the United States withdrew its motion for a preliminary injunction without prejudice (thereby allowing it to refile the motion in the future if necessary). The United States acted upon express assurances by defendants that if the court granted preliminary relief to plaintiffs, which it did, defendants would not seek to enforce SB 5375 "as [applied] to confession or sacred confidences shared with any clergy" for the duration of preliminary relief. 

This case is ongoing.

Plaintiffs sought a declaration that the state law was unconstitutional, a preliminary and permanent injunction against the criminal investigation of Catholic priests under the law, and attorneys' fees. On July 18, 2025, the court granted plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. This case is ongoing.

Plaintiffs sought a declaration that the state law was unconstitutional, a preliminary and permanent injunction against the criminal investigation of Catholic priests under the law, and attorneys' fees. The case was assigned to Judge David G. Estudillo.

2.transformed_text:
Washington state law SB 5375, which mandated priests report suspected child abuse or neglect disclosed in confession, faced a legal challenge. Confession, a foundational sacrament of the Catholic Church for two millennia, carries severe theological penalties, including "eternal damnation" and automatic excommunication, for priests who breach its confidentiality. While Washington's three Catholic dioceses already mandated reporting beyond state law, they excepted information learned exclusively via confession. Plaintiffs asserted the new state law violated the First Amendment, the Equal Protection Clause, and the Washington Constitution.

Eleven Catholic archbishops and priests, represented by Wilmer Hale and the Becket Fund for religious liberty, initiated the lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington on May 29, 2025. They named state and county prosecuting authorities as defendants, seeking a declaration of unconstitutionality, preliminary and permanent injunctive relief against criminal investigation of Catholic priests under the law, and attorneys' fees. Judge David G. Estudillo was assigned the case.

The United States intervened as a plaintiff, with the court reserving its ruling on the scope of relief it could seek. The United States also filed its own motion for a preliminary injunction.

The court granted plaintiffs' (not the United States') motion for a preliminary injunction. It found plaintiffs likely to succeed on their Free Exercise Clause claims, determining SB 5375 burdened their Catholic faith and uniquely modified existing law for clergy, unlike secular mandated reporters. The court further concluded the law failed strict scrutiny, noting Washington could adopt less restrictive approaches, as exemplified by 25 other states that make Catholic clergymen mandated reporters but exclude confession-derived information.

The court declined to address plaintiffs' Church Autonomy Doctrine and Establishment Clause claims. Consequently, defendants were enjoined from enforcing SB 5375 regarding the sacrament of confession across all three Washington Catholic dioceses. Injunctive relief was not sought or granted for faiths other than Catholicism.

The United States subsequently withdrew its preliminary injunction motion without prejudice. This withdrawal followed express assurances from defendants that, given the preliminary relief granted to plaintiffs, SB 5375 would not be enforced "as [applied] to confession or sacred confidences shared with any clergy" for the injunction's duration. The case remains ongoing.

3.transformed_text:
A federal court has issued a preliminary injunction against Washington state law SB 5375, which mandated priests report suspected child abuse or neglect disclosed in confession, effectively halting its enforcement against Catholic clergy.

*   Eleven Catholic archbishops and priests initiated the lawsuit, challenging SB 5375 as violative of the First Amendment and the Washington Constitution. They argued the law unconstitutionally burdened the foundational sacrament of confession, a practice with severe theological penalties for breach of confidentiality.
*   The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington granted plaintiffs' preliminary injunction, finding a likelihood of success on their Free Exercise Clause claims. The court determined SB 5375 burdened their Catholic faith, uniquely modified law for clergy, and failed strict scrutiny, noting 25 other states exclude confession-derived information.
*   Defendants, state and county prosecuting authorities, were enjoined from enforcing SB 5375 regarding the sacrament of confession across all three Washington Catholic dioceses. The court did not address other claims, and relief was confined to Catholicism.
*   The United States intervened as a plaintiff, later withdrawing its preliminary injunction motion without prejudice after defendants assured non-enforcement of SB 5375 "as [applied] to confession or sacred confidences shared with any clergy" for the injunction's duration. The case remains ongoing.

Federal Court Halts Washington Confession Reporting Law for Priests

*   **Who Sued Who?** Eleven Catholic archbishops and priests sued Washington state and county prosecuting authorities. The United States intervened as a plaintiff, later withdrawing its preliminary injunction motion without prejudice.
*   **Why?** Plaintiffs argued SB 5375, mandating priests report confession-disclosed abuse, violated First Amendment Free Exercise Clause rights by unconstitutionally burdening the sacrament of confession, a practice with severe theological penalties for breach of confidentiality.
*   **What Happened?** The U.S. District Court granted a preliminary injunction, halting SB 5375's enforcement against Catholic clergy regarding confession. The court found plaintiffs likely to succeed on Free Exercise Clause claims, determining the law burdened faith, uniquely modified law for clergy, and failed strict scrutiny. The court did not address other claims, and relief was confined to Catholicism.

Defendants were thus enjoined from enforcing SB 5375 as to the sacrament of confession across all three of Washington's Catholic dioceses. (Plaintiffs did not seek, and the court did not grant, injunctive relief to faiths other than Catholicism.)

On July 23, 2025, the United States withdrew its motion for a preliminary injunction without prejudice (thereby allowing it to refile the motion in the future if necessary). The United States acted upon express assurances by defendants that if the court granted preliminary relief to plaintiffs, which it did, defendants would not seek to enforce SB 5375 "as [applied] to confession or sacred confidences shared with any clergy" for the duration of preliminary relief. 

This case is ongoing.

This case challenged a Washington state law, Senate Bill 5375, which required priests to report suspected child abuse or neglect they learned about during confession. Confession is one of the seven sacraments of the Catholic Church and has been a core part of its beliefs for 2,000 years. A priest who breaks the confidentiality of confession faces "eternal damnation" and automatic removal from the Catholic Church.

Washington's three Catholic regions (dioceses) already required reporting of suspected child abuse, even more than state law demanded. However, they made an exception for information learned only through confession. The plaintiffs claimed the new state law violated their rights under the First Amendment, the Equal Protection Clause, and the Washington State Constitution.

Eleven Catholic archbishops and priests, represented by Wilmer Hale and the Becket Fund for religious liberty, filed this lawsuit. They sued in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington on May 29, 2025. They named the Governor, the Attorney General of Washington, and every County Prosecuting Attorney in the state as defendants. The plaintiffs asked the court to declare the state law unconstitutional. They also sought a preliminary and permanent order (an injunction) to stop criminal investigations of Catholic priests under this law, and to recover their legal fees. Judge David G. Estudillo was assigned to the case.

The United States government asked to join the case as a plaintiff on June 23, 2025. The court allowed the U.S. to join on July 15, 2025. However, it decided to rule later on how much relief the U.S. could ask for. The U.S. then filed its own request for a preliminary injunction on June 25, 2025, separate from the plaintiffs' earlier request.

On July 18, 2025, the court granted the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction (but not the U.S. government's). The court believed the plaintiffs would likely win their arguments that SB 5375 violated the Free Exercise Clause. This was because the law made it harder for plaintiffs to practice their Catholic faith. Also, the law changed existing rules only for religious leaders, not for other non-religious people who are required to report. The court also found the law failed "strict scrutiny," a high legal test. Washington could have adopted a less restrictive approach, like 25 other states. These states make Catholic clergy mandatory reporters but do not require them to report information learned only through confession.

The court did not rule on the plaintiffs' other claims, such as those based on the Church Autonomy Doctrine or the Establishment Clause. As a result, the defendants were ordered to stop enforcing SB 5375 regarding the sacrament of confession in all three of Washington's Catholic dioceses. (The plaintiffs did not ask for, and the court did not provide, this order for religions other than Catholicism.)

The U.S. government took this step because the defendants had promised that if the court granted the plaintiffs preliminary relief (which it did), they would not try to enforce SB 5375 concerning confession or other sacred confidences shared with any clergy while that preliminary order was in place.

3.transformed_text:
Imagine a new school rule that forces students to tell the principal everything they hear in private conversations, even if it's about something serious. Well, a Washington state law, called Senate Bill 5375, was kind of like that, but for priests. It said priests had to report suspected child abuse or neglect they heard during confession. Confession is a really important religious practice for Catholics. It's one of their seven "sacraments," which are sacred rituals, and it's been a core part of their faith for 2,000 years. If a priest breaks the secrecy of confession, they face very serious religious punishments, like being kicked out of the Catholic Church and facing what they believe is "eternal damnation."

Even before this new law, the three main Catholic areas in Washington (called "dioceses") already had their own rules for reporting suspected child abuse. In some ways, their rules were even tougher than the state's. But they made one big exception: priests didn't have to report things they heard *only* during confession. The people who sued (called "plaintiffs") argued that this new state law went against their rights. They said it violated the First Amendment, which protects religious freedom (like the right to practice your faith without the government interfering). They also said it violated the Equal Protection Clause, which means everyone should be treated fairly under the law, and the Washington State Constitution.

Eleven Catholic archbishops and priests, with help from lawyers at Wilmer Hale and a group called the Becket Fund for religious liberty, started this lawsuit. They took their case to a federal court, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington, on May 29, 2025. They sued the Governor, Washington's Attorney General (the state's top lawyer), and all the county prosecutors in the state. These officials were called the "defendants" – the ones being sued. The plaintiffs asked the court to say that the state law was "unconstitutional," which means it broke the rules of the U.S. Constitution. They also asked for a special court order, called an "injunction," to temporarily and then permanently stop any criminal investigations of Catholic priests under this law. And they wanted the government to pay for their legal costs. Judge David G. Estudillo was assigned to oversee the case.

Then, the U.S. government asked to join the lawsuit on June 23, 2025. They wanted to be another "plaintiff," meaning another party supporting the lawsuit. The court allowed the U.S. government to join on July 15, 2025. But the court said it would decide later what specific help or "relief" the U.S. government could ask for. The U.S. government then filed its own request for a temporary court order, or "preliminary injunction," on June 25, 2025. This was a separate request from the one the original plaintiffs had made.

On July 18, 2025, the court said "yes" to the original plaintiffs' request for a temporary injunction, but "no" to the U.S. government's request. The court thought the plaintiffs would probably win their case. It found that SB 5375 likely violated the "Free Exercise Clause" of the First Amendment, which protects your right to practice your religion freely without the government interfering. This was because the law made it harder for the plaintiffs to practice their Catholic faith. Also, the law changed rules only for religious leaders, but not for other non-religious people who are also required to report child abuse. The court also found that the law did not pass "strict scrutiny." This is a very tough legal test courts use to decide if a law that limits important rights is truly necessary. Washington could have used a less strict approach, like 25 other states do. These states require Catholic priests to report child abuse, but they don't force them to report information they heard *only* during confession.

The court didn't make a decision on the plaintiffs' other arguments. For example, they didn't rule on the "Church Autonomy Doctrine," which says religious groups should have the freedom to run their own affairs, or the "Establishment Clause," which stops the government from favoring one religion over others. Because of this, the defendants (the state officials) were ordered to stop enforcing SB 5375 when it came to the sacrament of confession in all three Catholic areas in Washington. (It's important to note that the plaintiffs only asked for this order for Catholicism, and the court didn't extend it to other religions.)

On July 23, 2025, the U.S. government decided to pull back its request for a temporary injunction. They did this "without prejudice," which is a legal term meaning they could ask for it again later if they needed to. The U.S. government did this because the defendants had promised that if the court gave the original plaintiffs a temporary order (which it did), they wouldn't try to enforce SB 5375 when it came to confession or other private, sacred talks shared with *any* religious leader, as long as that temporary order was in place.

This case is still ongoing.

And they said it broke the Washington State Constitution.

Eleven Catholic archbishops and priests started this lawsuit. Lawyers from Wilmer Hale and a group called the Becket Fund helped them. They went to a federal court on May 29, 2025. This court was the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington. They sued the Governor. They also sued Washington's top lawyer, the Attorney General. And they sued all the county prosecutors in the state. These officials were called the "defendants." They were the ones being sued. 1.transformed_text:
Washington state's SB 5375 created a profound dilemma for Catholic priests, demanding they report suspected child abuse or neglect disclosed during confession. This directly challenged a practice central to Catholic theology for two millennia, where breaking the seal of confession carries the severe penalty of "eternal damnation" and automatic excommunication. While Washington's Catholic dioceses already mandated reporting for most abuse cases, the law's unique targeting of information learned exclusively in confession forced priests into an irreconcilable conflict between their spiritual duties and legal obligations.

Faced with this direct assault on religious freedom, eleven Catholic archbishops and priests, represented by Wilmer Hale and the Becket Fund, initiated a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington. Their strategic purpose in filing this action was to defend the sanctity of confession and prevent the criminalization of their religious practices. They sought not only a declaration that the state law was unconstitutional but also an immediate preliminary injunction to halt its enforcement, recognizing the spiritual peril priests would face if forced to comply. The lawsuit named the Governor, Attorney General, and every County Prosecuting Attorney in Washington as defendants.

Recognizing the significant constitutional implications for religious liberty, the United States chose to join the plaintiffs' cause. Its intervention was a strategic move to lend federal support to the challenge against SB 5375, reinforcing the argument that the law infringed upon fundamental rights and aiming to ensure the broadest possible protection against its enforcement. The court granted the United States permission to intervene.

The court, perceiving the urgency of the situation and the strong likelihood that the plaintiffs' religious freedom was being violated, swiftly granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. This critical decision served as an immediate, temporary halt to the enforcement of SB 5375 regarding the sacrament of confession. The court's ruling signaled its preliminary view that the law likely overstepped constitutional bounds by burdening the plaintiffs' exercise of their Catholic faith, particularly as it modified existing law solely for clergy and failed to meet the high standard of strict scrutiny. The court noted that Washington could have followed the less restrictive approach of many other states, which make clergy mandated reporters but exclude information learned solely from confession.

Following the court's injunction, and upon receiving express assurances from the defendants that the state would not seek to enforce SB 5375 "as [applied] to confession or sacred confidences shared with any clergy" for the duration of preliminary relief, the United States withdrew its separate motion for a preliminary injunction. This move indicated that the immediate threat had been sufficiently mitigated, and the federal government's primary objective of protecting religious liberty had been, for the moment, achieved. The case remains ongoing.
